title: Vwaza Marsh Game Reserve
text:
Vwaza Marsh Game Reserve is a <a href="List%20of%20protected%20areas%20of%20Malawi">national game reserve</a> in <a href="Malawi">Malawi</a>.
In contrast to the <a href="Nyika%20National%20Park">Nyika National Park</a> on the <a href="Nyika%20Plateau">Nyika Plateau</a>, much of Vwaza is located on low-lying flat ground although the eastern side of the park is hilly. It is located to the southeast of the plateau and to the north of the floodplains of <a href="South%20Rukuru%20River">South Rukuru River</a> and covers an area of 1,000 km2.
The park is characterised by <a href="Mopane">Mopane</a> and <a href="Miombo">Miombo</a> woodland and marshy wetlands which attracts a significant number of birds to the reserve.
Vwaza Marsh Game Reserve is rarely visited by many, largely due to poor road conditions and difficult terrain and inaccessibility.
The variation in animal number of species type may vary from season to season as they cross the border with the <a href="North%20Luangwa%20National%20Park">North Luangwa National Park</a> in <a href="Zambia">Zambia</a>. Typically the reserve has large herds of <a href="African%20buffalo">Cape buffalo</a>es and <a href="African%20bush%20elephant">elephant</a>s, and a large variety of <a href="antelope">antelope</a> including <a href="Roan%20antelope">roan</a>, <a href="greater%20kudu">greater kudu</a>, <a href="Lichtenstein%27s%20hartebeest">Lichtenstein's hartebeest</a>, <a href="common%20eland">eland</a> and <a href="impala">impala</a>.
<a href="common%20warthog">Warthog</a>s are also found in this reserve as well as a <a href="hippopotamus">hippopotamus</a> pod in <a href="Lake%20Kazuni">Lake Kazuni</a>.
Moses the orphaned elephant that now is at Jumbo Foundation elephant orphanage in Lilongwe Malawi, was rescued by rangers at Vwaza marsh in the South Rukuru river. <a href="http%3A//www.jumbofoundation.com"></a>
Notable birdlife include <a href="Goliath%20heron">Goliath heron</a>s, <a href="openbill%20stork">openbill stork</a>s and the rare white-winged starling. <a href="Lake%20Kazuni">Lake Kazuni</a> is located in the reserve and supports a notable <a href="hippo">hippo</a> population.
Site has a wide variety of plants communities and there are 398 species of vascular plants from 71 families.
